conclusion: The curved surface of the water-mist drop is part of a sphere with center O.
Any light ray passing through O meets the spherical surface normally and is not refracted.
The segment of the path inside the mist is exactly the radius r of the hemisphere.
Inside the mist, the ray reaches the flat base at O and strikes the interface with the same direction for every color.
Denote the angle which the incident ray makes with the normal to the flat surface by θi.
For the B-ray, the emergent angle with the normal in air is 45° and its refractive index is √2.
Using Snell's law, sin θi = 1/2, thus θi = 30°.
Every color traveling along this radius meets the flat interface at 30° to the normal.
For the A-ray, the angle it makes with the interface is 30°.
The angle with the normal for the A-ray is 60° in air.
The speed of light for the A-ray inside the mist is vA = c / √3.
The time spent inside the hemisphere is tA = √3 r / c.
The propagation time of the A-ray inside the water-mist hemisphere is t = (√3 r) / c.
